messageBody:
Ole,



I am not sure if you can do that in Maven. But I think it might be
worth thinking about passing in the base folder to your class under test
(Dependency Injection Pattern) rather than having the class computing
it. In situations like that I sometime use in my class under test a
setter method for a base folder that I only use in a test environment.
The class under test checks if the folder is already set, if not, it
does the standard behavior in computing the current folder, etc. You
could have a check for null and since the setter method is not used in
production, the variable would be null in production.



Andreas

directory is well-encapsulated?

ole_ersoy wrote:
> Hi,
>
> Does anyone know whether I can specify which directory
> a junit test will run in.
>
> Let me elaborate a little.
>
> I'm using Maven to run the tests, but in this case I want the
> test to think that it is running in a directory "src/test/output"
> relative to the directory that the tests are launced from.
>
> In other words I want the JUnit test to think it is being run from
>
> $basedir/src/test/output, when I'm really running it from $basedir.
>
> The component I'm testing creates directories, so my end goal is to
> have that component create the directories relative to
>
> $basedir/src/test/output
>
> Thanks,
